data.text:
Timothy Dalton`s incarnation of James Bond deserves better recognition than he gets.

Portraying the British spy on two occasions, his films did not receive the cultural recognition that many of his Bondian counterparts got.

Often unfairly criticised by some critics, Dalton was frequently called miscast. These criticisms are completely arbitrary and misguided.Dalton stands heads and shoulders over the other Bond actors and revitalised the Bond serieswith his terrific portrayal.

What made him the best? First of all, Dalton`s acting credentials have been unbeatable. The finest thespian to play Bond to date, Timothy Dalton made his name as a Shakespearian stage actor in the sixties. On screen, he held his own in The Lion in Winter (1968), Wuthering Heights (1970), Mary, Queen of Scots (1972) and Permission to Kill (1975). Other celebrated parts include a starring role in Hawks, the film version of Jane Eyre, the stage version of Northern Lights and as Rhett Butler in the television drama Scarlett.

Dalton had a penchant to play villains also, as evident in his scene stealing turns in Flash Gordon and Hot Fuzz, giving him the perfect ammunition to play James Bond as an anti-hero when offered the part in 1986.

A trained actor as opposed to a Hollywood star; Dalton was perfect for the role.

Out of the six Bonds, it is Dalton who Ian Fleming would almost certainly have been happiest with.Dark haired, tall and thin, Dalton was very similar in appearance to the character described in the

books (the same cannot be said about the fair haired Roger Moore, the blocky Sean Connery or the short, blonde haired Daniel Craig). Making the conscious decision not to imitate Sean Connery, Roger Moore or

George Lazenby Dalton studied the James Bond that was described in Ian Fleming`s

novels.

A fan of the books, as well as Sean Connery`s first three outings, Dalton wanted to play the character in a grittier manner than previously seen. Dalton even looked after the minor details, such as the literary Bond`s excessive smoking habit.

Although Daniel Craig is frequently credited with being

the first “serious” Bond, it was Dalton who first played James Bond as a no nonsense spy. And he played the part so much better than Craig did!

Enthusiastic about the role, Dalton threw himself into the stunt work. Dalton clung to land rovers,hung off dangerous cliffs and jumped over Moroccan building tops over the course of his two films.

This gave his films a realistic thrill that was not seen in many of the Roger Moore or Pierce Brosnan films and the chase in Tangiers featured in The Living Daylights is rumoured to have inspired a similar one in The Bourne Ultimatum (2008).

When dressing himself, Dalton looked smart in suits and

avoided wearing the embarrassing kilts and safari suits worn by George Lazenby and Roger Moore respectively.

Amongst other pros he was, arguably, the handsomest to play the part to date, reinstating

a sex appeal that had been absent from the films since Connery.

But what was so special about his portrayal? What makes his Bond more impressive than the rest?

Simply put, Dalton re-imagined Bond in a more radical manner than his predecessors or successors.

Instead of consorting in clown suits, Dalton`s Bond was a credible assassin whose dark portrayal makes for intense viewing. Playing James Bond as if he were a real character, Dalton paid less attention to the clichéd quips in favour of aggressive responses. Telling MI6 operatives to stuff their

orders, and others to “piss off”, Dalton made Bond more human. Dalton`s Bond was one who disobeyed his orders, questioned needless killing and made him more three dimensional.

If it was not for Dalton, it is unlikely that Brosnan`s Bond or Craig`s Bond would have spoken about their professions so frankly in Goldeneye and Casino Royale respectively.

Dalton`s Bond was a more

modern man, less chauvinistic and more of a feminine egalitarian than his predecessors (a tradition

which may have led to Judi Dench being cast as M in the nineties).

As for humour? Dalton`s Bond

was less obvious about it.

Eschewing eye brow raising puns for lines of greater sustenance. His

marginality of quips made them funnier when he did eventually state them.

Less is Moore, as they

say!

hat was the greatest disappointment of the series?

It was that Dalton did not get to make more films

than he did.

Two outings do not suffice.

Dalton should have made a third, but lost the chance due to

ongoing legal implications between EON and MGM.

Had he gotten the chance, he would very likely

be remembered as the best Bond.

How do his films fare up? The Living Daylights (1987) is one of

the best in the series, and should rank in the top five.

Licence To Kill (1989) is not as strong, but it

should be credited for being one of the more original in the series.

All in all, the films were graced

with a superb actor who brought a depth to the character that revitalised the series.

Nobody does it

better than Dalton!
